docs.title: What is TerminalDrawer?
docs.text:
TerminalDrawer is a simple program, that allows you to draw stuff in the terminal

It was made for fun, and intended to learn the C++ programming language. You may use it in your application(s) if you want to, although I don't see a use for it.

docs.title: How do I use it?
docs.text: You'll have to build it yourself, see this page

docs.title: Building the program
docs.text: TerminalDrawer does not provide the binaries by default, so you'll have to built the program youself.

docs.title: Using CMAKE
docs.text:
Assuming you have CMAKE installed you simply run the following commands:

mkdir build
cd build
cmake .. && make

This should successfully build the program, and make it available at build/TerminalDrawer.

docs.title: Modes
docs.text: TerminalDrawer offers 2 modes to run in. CSV mode and Clock mode.

docs.title: CSV Mode
docs.text:
The CSV mode allow you to draw points in the terminal from a CSV file.

For example, the following file will draw a simple point at the column 10, row 10, with the name(what the program should draw at the coordinates provided).

10, 10, test

So in the terminal type:

TerminalDrawer --no-start --csv
    #What csv file would you like to use? (*.csv) {enter name of file here}

The status bar was enabled with the --status option

docs.title: Clock Mode
docs.text:
This mode can be enabled by adding the --clock when running the program, or by telling it in the start screen.

It will display a clock that moves similar to the popular DVD logo animation

docs.title: --no-start
docs.text: Disables the start screen that's enabled by default.

docs.title: --csv
docs.text: Enters the CSV mode, if --no-start is enabled

docs.title: --clock
docs.text: Enters the Clock mode, if --no-start is enabled
